awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Industrial scale production of high-performance, in-home water filters to protect public health from lead and arsenic in drinking water.
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnership for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project will help to improve access to safe and reliable drinking water supplies by ensuring safe and healthy water at the point where it is used or consumed. The proposed nanotechnology-enabled water filter technology provides a unique solution to drinking water pollutants, such as lead and arsenic, as an in-home or point-of-use (POU) technology.  The technology could be used for unregulated water supplies like private drinking water wells, where water is often consumed with little to no treatment; day care centers, schools, offices, and other settings with extensive use of fountains and bubblers; or circumstances with limited freshwater resources, such as natural disasters or humanitarian missions.

The proposed project will advance nanotechnology-enabled water treatment devices toward application scale. The project will (i) scale up electrospinning processes to fabricate nanofiber membrane sheets of dimensions necessary for integration into POU treatment devices; (ii) integrate these nanofiber membrane sheets into prototype POU treatment platforms to demonstrate ease of installation, use, and maintenance; and (iii) validate the device for removal of lead and arsenic under conditions typical of consumer product certification. These composite nanofiber water filters are innovative because of their (i) simple, highly tunable synthetic approach; (ii) higher external surface area (rather than internal porosity) enabling fast, non-diffusion limited rates of target removal; (iii) scalability, enabling application across a range of end users; and (iv) multi-functionality derived from co-integrated ion exchange and sorbent sites. The transformative aspect of this technology relates to our ability to exploit synthesis processes to create multi-functional, nanostructured materials with synergistic performance characteristics; the technology relies on a simple “one-pot” electrospinning synthesis for creation of a robust platform that is surface-enriched with multiple binding agents for metal capture.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This PFI-TT award supported a collaboration between academic researchers at the University of Iowa and the University of Notre Dame and an industrial partner, Nanofiber Solutions, Inc., to develop an innovative point-of-use (POU) water filter made from polymer-metal oxide nanofiber composites. Using the industrially proven fabrication technique of electrospinning, the nanofiber composites are designed to selectively bind lead, a potent neurotoxin that threatens the drinking water of millions of Americans. Innovation in our technology is derived from both the novel fabrication and dual functionality of these nanofiber composite filter materials. We have developed a patented, single-pot synthesis approach that exploits unique interactions between metal oxide nanoparticles and simple organic acids to produce nanofibers that are surface-enriched with binding agents for the selective removal of lead from drinking water. These nanofiber composites possess a high external surface area, enabling rapid, high-capacity sorption of lead at levels that meet or exceed other commercially available sorbents. Moreover, electrospinning yields a three-dimensional nanofiber mesh that also functions as a high-flux microfiltration membrane suitable for the physical removal of suspended particles. The net result is improved performance and reliability of our filter material relative to existing commercial alternatives for lead, which can pose a risk to human health in drinking water both in dissolved and particulate forms.

Specific research outcomes of this award included the development of an optimal formulation for the nanofibers in the POU device that use low-cost, readily available commercial ingredients (e.g., iron oxides and simple organic acids) and a robust yet flexible polymer matrix (nylon) that allows for the nanofiber membrane sheets to be easily integrated into a POU filter device. Another major research outcome was our ability to demonstrate that electrospinning synthesis recipes developed at the laboratory bench scale could be translated to industrial-scale, high-throughput production routes including needleless electrospinning and high-volume, multi-needle assemblies. Indeed, we have successfully demonstrated the scalability of our fabrication approach, which was the primary goal of our PFI-TT proposal. Using the optimal filter formulation, we also built a prototype POU filter and tested its performance for lead removal under conditions (e.g., pressure and flow rates) simulating in-home use. These performance tests illustrate promising removal capacity for our filter materials under simulated POU treatment, in which the thickness of the nanofiber layer dictates the extent of lead removal and the overall lifetime of the filter. Collectively, this work contributed to the receipt of two patents and the submission of an additional patent application, while also supporting dissemination of research products through multiple manuscripts and meeting presentations.

In addition to traditional research outcomes, this PFI-TT award supported technology translation efforts of the research team. As part of this award, the research team completed I-Corps training in Fall 2020 in Cohort 3 (St. Louis/virtual) as Team 2070 FilterMore. Our team consisted of Entrepreneurial Lead Humberto Gonzalez-Ribot, co-Technical Leads David Cwiertny and Nosang Myung, and Industry Mentor Jed Johnson (co-PI) of Nanofiber Solutions, Inc. We used customer discovery to establish our beachhead market of schools and daycares, with our minimum viable product (MVP) being a POU filter that targets lead removal. Based on our plan to functionalize existing block carbon filters with nanofiber sorbent layers, we believe we can extend the lifetime of commercially available, certified lead removal devices by at least two-fold. This, in turn, would limit filter replacement and maintenance, both of which were important value propositions for our customer segment of school and daycare facilities administrators. Currently, we are testing and optimizing the prototype filter developed over the past project period to meet this performance target. Our focus on schools and daycares is motivated by recent updates to federal regulations (the Lead and Copper Rule) that will require testing in schools starting in 2024.  As federally mandated testing is conducted, and lead contamination problems are revealed, schools will need versatile technologies to remove lead from drinking water as costs of plumbing repairs may be too-cost prohibitive for most school districts.

Over the lifetime of this PFI-TT award, resources have supported the training of several academic researchers, from undergraduate to post-doctoral, across all participating institutions (University of Iowa, the University of Notre Dame and Nanofiber Solutions, Inc.). All project participants worked on a highly collaborative, interdisciplinary team spanning academia and industry. Participation on such an interdisciplinary team and across academic and industrial partners has helped to better prepare participants on this project for a diversity of careers, including those beyond academia and at the interface of research and industry, upon the completion of their degrees and research appointments.
